PT J
AN ZOOR15505030739
DT Article
TI A new Typhloreicheia species from central Sardinia, sampled in hypogean
   environment in 'Tacco del Sarcidano' (Coleoptera, Carabidae,
   Scaritinae).
FT Una nuova Typhloreicheia della Sardegna centrale, campionata in ambiente
   ipogeo nel Tacco del Sarcidano (Coleoptera, Carabidae, Scaritinae).
AU Magrini, Paolo (duvalius@paolomagrini.it) 
   Onnis, Carlo
   Casale, Achille
SO Giornale Italiano di Entomologia
VL 15
IS 64
PS 361-372
PD Mar 2019
PY 2019
LA Italian
U1 0
U2 1
AB The authors describe Typhloreicheia puddui n. sp., sampled in two caves
   located in the "Tacco del Sarcidano" area (central Sardinia): Is
   Breccas, Su Disterru de Lorita cave (800 m a.s.l.), and Funtana de
   Tetti, Sa Sperradura de Tetti cave (650 m a.s.l.), both in the Gadoni
   territory. The new species, both for external characters and the
   structure of male genitalia, is close to Typhloreicheia carlonnisi
   Magrini, Marcia & Casale, 2011, from which it is markedly distinct by
   the following characteristics: more elongate body, shorter antennae,
   less developed denticulation at elytral sides, aedeagus in lateral
   aspect wider at apex, copulatory piece of the endophallus wider and more
   sclerified, median lobe of the aedeagus in ventral aspect very
   differently shaped, not straight but turned to the left, left paramere
   wider, provided with three setae (two in T. carlonnisi).
C1 Magrini, Paolo; Univ Firenze, Sez Zool La Specola, Via Romana 17,
   Florence, FI, I-50125, Italy, Italy.
EM duvalius@paolomagrini.it
SC Zoology
SN 0392-7296
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Europe; Italy
DE Typhloreicheia puddui [Sardinia /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Adephaga, Caraboidea,
   Carabidae
OR Typhloreicheia puddui (Carabidae): [Sp nov, Sardinia, P. 364]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15505030739

PT J
AN ZOOR15505030740
DT Article
TI On the identity of Reicheia balearica Espanol, 1974, with establishment
   of the new genus Gymnetoreicheia (Coleoptera, Carabidae, Scaritinae,
   Clivinini).
FT Sull'identita di Reicheia balearica Espanol, 1974, con istituzione del
   nuovo genere Gymnetoreicheia (Coleoptera, Carabidae, Scaritinae,
   Clivinini).
AU Magrini, Paolo (duvalius@paolomagrini.it) 
   Fancello, Luca
   Casale, Achille
SO Giornale Italiano di Entomologia
VL 15
IS 64
PS 373-390
PD Mar 2019
PY 2019
LA Italian
U1 0
U2 0
AB Reicheia balearica Espanol, 1974 from Mallorca (Balearic Islands,
   Spain), known so far only from hypogean habitat, and the only species of
   Reicheiina known from the Balearic Islands, is re-examined based on four
   specimens from the type locality. Owing to the absence of the basal
   border of pronotum and other important morphological characteristics of
   the exoskeleton and genitalia as well, the species is recognized as
   foreign to the genus Reicheia Saulcy, 1862 and attributed to the new,
   monospecific, genus Gymnetoreicheia Magrini, Fancello & Casale, with the
   new combination Gymnetoreicheia balearica (Espanol, 1974). The new genus
   is compared with the other Mediterranean genera characterized by
   vanished basal border of pronotum.
C1 Magrini, Paolo; Univ Firenze, Sez Zool La Specola, Via Romana 17,
   Florence, FI, I-50125, Italy, Italy.
EM duvalius@paolomagrini.it
SC Zoology
SN 0392-7296
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Combination
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Adephaga, Caraboidea,
   Carabidae
OR Gymnetoreicheia (Carabidae): [Gen nov, Of tribe Clivinini, Type species
   Reicheia balearica Espanol 1974, p. 376]. 
   Gymnetoreicheia balearica - (Espanol 1974) (Carabidae): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Reicheia, p. 376]. 
   Reicheia balearica - Espanol 1974 (Carabidae): [Designated type species
   for new genus, Gymnetoreicheia, p. 376]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15505030740

PT J
AN ZOOR15505030741
DT Article
TI On the systematic position of Typhloreicheia bavierai Magrini,
   Degiovanni & Petrioli, 2010 with establishment of a new Sicilian genus
   (Coleoptera, Carabidae, Scaritinae, Clivinini).
FT Sulla posizione sistematica di Typhloreicheia bavierai Magrini,
   Degiovanni & Petrioli, 2010 con istituzione di un nuovo genere siciliano
   (Coleoptera, Carabidae, Scaritinae, Clivinini).
AU Magrini, Paolo (duvalius@paolomagrini.it) 
   Fancello, Luca
SO Giornale Italiano di Entomologia
VL 15
IS 64
PS 391-400
PD Mar 2019
PY 2019
LA Italian
U1 0
U2 0
AB Based on new morphological studies, Typhloreicheia bavierai Magrini,
   Degiovanni & Petrioli, 2010, Sicilian endemism restricted to the cave
   Grotta del Sughero (Scopello, Trapani), is considered foreign to the
   genus Typhloreicheia Holdhaus, 1924, and assigned to the new,
   monospecific genus Sikelioreicheia Magrini & Fancello gen. nov.
   (Sikelioreicheia bavierai (Magrini, Degiovanni & Petrioli, 2010) comb.
   nov.). For the presence on the pronotum of a median longitudinal sulcus
   vanished backwards, and of a distinct prebasal border slightly curved at
   middle and separate from the median longitudinal sulcus, the new genus
   is considered closer to Reicheia Saulcy, 1862 rather than
   Typhloreicheia. Other useful characteristic to isolate Sikelioreicheia
   from Reicheia and Typhloreicheia is the marginal elytral hollow, in the
   first very flattened, long, and especially starting at the base of the
   4th stria, rather than 5th; the complete anophthalmia and the extreme
   flattening of the body (important by a diagnostic, but not phyletic
   point of view) further characterize the new genus.
C1 Magrini, Paolo; Univ Firenze, Museo Storia Nat, Via Romana 17, Florence,
   FI, I-50125, Italy, Italy.
EM duvalius@paolomagrini.it
SC Zoology
SN 0392-7296
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Combination
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Adephaga, Caraboidea,
   Carabidae
OR Sikelioreicheia (Carabidae): [Gen nov, Of tribe Clivinini, Type species
   Typhloreicheia bavierai Magrini, Degiovanni & Petrioli 2010, p. 395]. 
   Sikelioreicheia bavierai - (Magrini, Degiovanni & Petrioli 2010)
   (Carabidae): [Comb nov, Transferred from Typhloreicheia, p. 395]. 
   Typhloreicheia bavierai - Magrini, Degiovanni & Petrioli 2010
   (Carabidae): [Designated type species for new genus, Sikelioreicheia, p.
   395]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15505030741
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR15505030742
DT Article
TI Notes on the tribe Rhopalomelini Alluaud, 1930 with descriptions of two
   new genera and two new species (Coleoptera, Carabidae, Chlaeniinae).
AU Sciaky, Riccardo (riccardo.sciaky@virgilio.it) 
   Facchini, Sergio
SO Giornale Italiano di Entomologia
VL 15
IS 64
PS 401-412
PD Mar 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Some genera of the tribe Rhopalomelini of the subfamily Chlaeniinae from
   the Afrotropical region are here dealed with, proposing the new synonymy
   Procletini Basilewsky, 1950 = Rhopalomelini Alluaud, 1930 n. syn. Two
   new genera and two new species of this tribe are described and the
   habitus and male genitalia of the taxa are illustrated. Straneomelus n.
   gen. (type-species Parachlaenius marshalli Straneo, 1947) is established
   for two species previously attributed to Parachlaenius, and a new
   synonymy is proposed: Parachlaenius rhodesianus Straneo, 1947 =
   Parachlaenius bequaerti Alluaud, 1930 n. syn. Globulipalpus n. gen. is
   established for the new species Globulipalpus stenomandibularis n. sp.
   (type-species) and G. castionii n. sp. A key to all the genera belonging
   to this tribe is also provided.
C1 Sciaky, Riccardo; Via Fiamma 13, Milan, MI, I-20129, Italy, Italy.
EM riccardo.sciaky@virgilio.it
SC Zoology
SN 0392-7296
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Combination;
   Synonymy; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Key; Land zones; Afrotropical
   region; Africa
DE Globulipalpus castionii [Gabon /  / New species]. 
   Globulipalpus stenomandibularis [Zambia /  / New species]. 
   Rhopalomelini [Afrotropical region /  / Systematics]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Adephaga, Caraboidea,
   Carabidae
OR Globulipalpus (Carabidae): [Gen nov, Of tribe Rhopalomelini, Type
   species Globulipalpus stenomandibularis, p. 405]. 
   Globulipalpus castionii (Carabidae): [Sp nov, Gabon, P. 408]. 
   Globulipalpus stenomandibularis (Carabidae): [Sp nov, Zambia, P. 408]. 
   Parachlaenius bequaerti - Alluaud 1930 (Carabidae): [Referred to,
   Straneomelus, p. 403]. 
   Parachlaenius marshalli - Straneo 1947 (Carabidae): [Designated type
   species for new genus, Straneomelus, p. 402]. 
   Rhopalomelini - Alluaud 1930 (Carabidae): [Syn nov, Procletini
   Basilewsky 1950, p. 402; Key to genera, P. 410]. 
   Straneomelus (Carabidae): [Gen nov, Of tribe Rhopalomelini, Type species
   Parachlaenius marshalli Straneo 1947, p. 402]. 
   Straneomelus bequaerti - (Alluaud 1930) (Carabidae): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Parachlaenius, p. 403; Syn nov, Parachlaenius
   rhodesianus Straneo 1947, p. 403]. 
   Straneomelus marshalli - (Straneo 1947) (Carabidae): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Parachlaenius, p. 403]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15505030742

AN ZOOR15505030743
DT Article
TI The Agrilini of the Institute Nacional de Pesquisas da Amazonia (INPA),
   Manaus, Brazil, with faunistic considerations on the Brazilian Mata
   Amazonica (Coleoptera, Buprestidae).
AU Curletti, Gianfranco (giancurletti@gmail.com) 
SO Giornale Italiano di Entomologia
VL 15
IS 64
PS 413-426
PD Mar 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A list of the Buprestidae Agrilini in the collections of the Institute
   Nacional de Pesquisas da Amazonia (INPA), Manaus, Brazil, is provided.
   Five new species are described: Agrilus (Agrilus) rafaeli n. sp.,
   Agrilus (Agrilus) chiarae n. sp., Agrilus (Agrilus) duckei n. sp.,
   Agrilus (Agrilus) aurofissum n. sp., Agrilus (Agrilus) tubulinus n. sp.
   Considerations are made concerning the Agrilofauna of the Mata
   Amazonica, focalizing its affinity with that of French Guiana, and its
   substantial difference from the fauna of the Mata Atlantica. Finally,
   the scarcity of research in the Amazon basin is highlighted.
C1 Curletti, Gianfranco; Museo Civ Storia Nat, Carmagnola, TO, I-10022,
   Italy, Italy.
EM giancurletti@gmail.com
SC Education &Educational Research; Zoology
SN 0392-7296
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Animals and man; Education and
   entertainment; Documentation; Publications; Land zones; Neotropical
   region; South America
DE Agrilini [Museums collections and exhibitions / Institute Nacional de
   Pesquisas da Amazonia collection / New record; systematics] [Checklists
   / Checklist of specimens / ] [Brazil / Manaus / ]. 
   Agrilus (Agrilus) aurofissum; Agrilus (Agrilus) chiarae; Agrilus
   (Agrilus) duckei; Agrilus (Agrilus) rafaeli; Agrilus (Agrilus) tubulinus
   [Brazil /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Buprestoidea,
   Buprestidae

   Agrilus (Agrilus) aurofissum (Buprestidae): [Sp nov, Brazil, P. 423]. 
   Agrilus (Agrilus) chiarae (Buprestidae): [Sp nov, Brazil, P. 422]. 
   Agrilus (Agrilus) duckei (Buprestidae): [Sp nov, Brazil, P. 423]. 
   Agrilus (Agrilus) rafaeli (Buprestidae): [Sp nov, Brazil, P. 422]. 
   Agrilus (Agrilus) tubulinus (Buprestidae): [Sp nov, Brazil, P. 424].

AN ZOOR15505030744
DT Article
TI Description of Boldoriella (Insubrites) trezzii n. sp. from the
   Presolana massif (Bergamo Pre-Alps) (Coleoptera, Carabidae, Trechinae).
FT Descrizione di Boldoriella (Insubrites) trezzii n. sp. del massiccio
   della Presolana (Prealpi Bergamasche) (Coleoptera, Carabidae,
   Trechinae).
AU Monguzzi, Riccardo (riccardo.monguzzi@gmail.com) 
SO Giornale Italiano di Entomologia
VL 15
IS 64
PS 427-434
PD Mar 2019
PY 2019
LA Italian
U1 0
U2 0
AB Boldoriella trezzii n. sp., belonging to the subgenus Insubrites
   Monguzzi, 1982, and particularly related to B. serianensis (Breit,
   1913), is described from a small artificial cave near Giogo della
   Presolana (Bergamo Pre-Alps). It is very surprising that at the same
   restricted geographical area, where the type locality of the new taxon
   is located - the calcareous-dolomitic Presolana massif - three other
   distinct species of the same subgenus Insubrites (Boldoriella
   serianensis (Breit, 1913), B. binaghii Bucciarellii, 1978 and B.
   pesarinii Sciaky, 1982) are already known. Therefore, for comparison
   purposes, the male genitalia of these three taxa are also illustrated.
C1 Monguzzi, Riccardo; Via M Malpighi 8, Milan, MI, I-20129, Italy, Italy.
EM riccardo.monguzzi@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 0392-7296
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Europe
DE Boldoriella (Insubrites) [Italy / Bergamo, central & oriental /
   Distribution]. 
   Boldoriella (Insubrites) trezzii [Italy /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Adephaga, Caraboidea,
   Carabidae
OR Boldoriella (Insubrites) (Carabidae). 
   Boldoriella (Insubrites) trezzii (Carabidae): [Sp nov, Italy, P. 427]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15505030744

TI Five New Taxa of Copris (Coleoptera: Scarabaeidae) from Vietnam and
   Laos.
AU Ochi, Teruo
   Kon, Masahiro
   Hong Thai Pham
SO Giornale Italiano di Entomologia
VL 15
IS 64
PS 435-446
PD Mar 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Four new taxa of Copris Muller, 1776 are described from Vietnam: C.
   (Copris) marcoberrai sp. nov.; C. (Paracopris) bartolozzii sp. nov.; C.
   (P.) tnontreuili sp. nov.; C. (P.) punctulatus septentrionalis ssp. nov.
   A new species of Copris is also described from Laos: C. (Copris)
   parasonensis sp. nov.

TI Four New Species of the Genera Odontotrypes and Phelotrupes (Coleoptera:

AB Three new species of Odontotrypes are described from China: O.
   (Thorectomimus) marcoberrai sp. nov. from Yunnan, O. (Odontotrypes)
   xizangensis sp. nov. from Xizang, and O. (O.) cobaltipennis sp. nov.
   from Sichuan. A new species of Phelotrupes is also described from
   Sichuan: P. (Phelotrupes) luhuoensis sp. nov.

DT Article
TI Three new species of the Genus Loxoncus Schmidt-Gobel, 1846 from
   continental Africa (Coleoptera Carabidae, Harpalinae).
AU Facchini, S. (sfacchini@virgilio.it) 
SO Giornale Italiano di Entomologia
VL 15
IS 64
PS 479-494
PD Mar 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Three new species of the genus Loxoncus Schmidt-Gobel, 1846 are
   described from continental Africa: Loxoncus schuelei n. sp., L.
   similatus n. sp., L. trochantericus n. sp. Illustrations of the habitus,
   drawings of the male genitalia, as well as distribution maps of the new
   species are provided. Moreover, the following systematic changes are
   proposed: Stenolophus amoenulus Peringuey, 1896 is a true species, not a
   synonym of Anoplogenius angustatus Chaudoir, 1878, which is a junior
   synonym of Stenolophus agyzimbanus Fairmaire, 1868.
C1 Facchini, S.; Via Prati 12, Piacenza, PC, I-29121, Italy, Italy.
EM sfacchini@virgilio.it
SC Zoology
SN 0392-7296

   Documentation; Publications; Land zones; Afrotropical region; Africa

   [Mozambique /  / ] [Namibia /  / ] [South Africa /  / ] [Tanzania /  /
   ]. 
   Loxoncus trochantericus [Congo-Kinshasa /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates

   Carabidae

   Stenolophus agyzimbanus Fairmaire 1868, p. 490; Removal from synonymy,
   Stenolophus amoenulus Peringuey 1896, p. 490]. 
   Loxoncus - Schmidt-Goebel 1846 (Carabidae): [Key to species, Modified to
   include new species., p. 485]. 
   Loxoncus schuelei (Carabidae): [Sp nov, Central African Republic, P.
   480]. 
   Loxoncus similatus (Carabidae): [Sp nov, South Africa, P. 484]. 
   Loxoncus trochantericus (Carabidae): [Sp nov, Congo-Kinshasa, P. 487]. 
   Stenolophus agyzimbanus - Fairmaire 1868 (Carabidae): [Senior synonym,
   Of Anoplogenius angustatus Chaudoir 1878, p. 490]. 
   Stenolophus amoenulus - Peringuey 1896 (Carabidae): [Removal from
   synonymy, With Anoplogenius angustatus Chaudoir 1878, p. 490].

PT J
AN ZOOR15505030751
DT Article
TI A new species belonging to the genus Domene Fauvel, 1873 (subg.
   Lathromene Koch, 1938) from Portugal (Coleoptera, Staphylinidae,
   Paederinae).
FT Una nuova specie appartenente al genere Domene Fauvel, 1873 (subg.
   Lathromene Koch, 1938) del Portogallo (Coleoptera, Staphylinidae,
   Paederinae).
AU Magrini, Paolo (duvalius@paolomagrini.it) 
   Carotti, Giovanni
SO Giornale Italiano di Entomologia
VL 15
IS 64
PS 495-502
PD Mar 2019
PY 2019
LA Italian
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new Domene (subg. Lathromene) is described from an abandoned mine in
   northern Portugal: Gruta Maria Isabel (Vila Real, Campea). The new
   species appears different from the others known for the exoskeleton and
   aedeagal characteristics as well. Unusual the great development of the
   aedeagal ventral lamina, in lateral view very long plough - shaped, and
   in ventral view parallel-sided (sides also sinuous) spearhead - shaped.
   The ventral lamina is very protruding from the body of the median lobe
   of the aedeagus, and it is the largest and the most prominent among all
   the known Iberian Lathromene species, together with Domene (Lathromene)
   orense Struyve, 2018.
C1 Magrini, Paolo; Univ Firenze, Museo Storia Nat, Via Romana 17, Florence,
   FI, I-50125, Italy, Italy.
EM duvalius@paolomagrini.it

   Eurasia; Europe

PT J
AN ZOOR15505030752
DT Article
TI Notes on Otiorhynchus (Lixorrhynchus) gracilis (Gyllenhal, 1834), with
   establishment of the new subgenus Italorrhynchus (Coleoptera,
   Curculionidae, Entiminae).
FT Note su Otiorhynchus (Lixorrhynchus) gracilis (Gyllenhal, 1834), con
   istituzione del nuovo sottogenere ltalorrhynchus (Coleoptera,
   Curculionidae, Entiminae).
AU Magrini, P. (duvalius@paolomagrini.it) 
SO Giornale Italiano di Entomologia
VL 15
IS 64
PS 503-520
PD Mar 2019
PY 2019
LA Italian
U1 0
U2 0
AB In the present note it is highlighted how all the Italian species
   considered belonging to the subgenus Lixorrhynchus Reitter, 1914 of
   Otiorhynchus Germar, 1822 are clearly different from the type species of
   the subgenus, O. (Lixorrhynchus) gracilis (Gyllenhal, 1834). Based on
   specimens of O. (L.) gracilis from its type locality, the Sainte-Baume
   massif (Marseilles, France), it is evident that the Italian taxa have
   different habitus, with narrower and longer elytra (length to width
   elytral ratio > 1.7; <= 1.5 in O. (L.) gracilis), the pronotum with
   sunken areolas (rather than with clearly prominent tubercles), different
   aedeagus, with the median lobe parallel-sided in ventral view (rather
   than tapering towards apexes), spiculum ventrale (8th sternite)
   differently shaped. Hence, I establish for the Italian "Lixorrhynchus"
   the new subgenus Italorrhynchus, with Otiorhynchus (Italorrhynchus)
   latirostris (Bargagli, 1871) as type species. The systematic position of
   the other, non Italian, taxa at present attributed to Lixorrhynchus
   needs to be clarified, though I think that most of them belong to the
   new subgenus.
C1 Magrini, P.; Univ Firenze, Sez Zool La Specola, Via Romana 17, Florence,
   FI, I-50125, Italy, Italy.
EM duvalius@paolomagrini.it
SC Zoology
SN 0392-7296
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Curculionoidea,
   Curculionidae
OR Otiorhynchus (Italorrhynchus) (Curculionidae): [Subgen nov, Type species
   Otiorhynchus latirostris (Bargagli 1871), p. 506]. 
   Otiorhynchus latirostris - (Bargagli 1871) (Curculionidae): [Designated
   type species for new subgenus, Otiorhynchus (Italorrhynchus), p. 506].

PT J
AN ZOOR15505030753
DT Article
TI The Mediterranean Reicheiina with vanished pronotal prebasal edge, with
   description of a new genus from Sardinia (Coleoptera, Carabidae,
   Scaritinae, Clivinini).
FT I Reicheiina mediterranei a orlo prebasale del pronoto svanito, con
   descrizione di un nuovo genere di Sardegna (Coleoptera, Carabidae,
   Scaritinae, Clivinini).
AU Magrini, Paolo (duvalius@paolomagrini.it) 
   Fancello, Luca
   Onnis, Carlo
SO Giornale Italiano di Entomologia
VL 15
IS 64
PS 521-544
PD Mar 2019
PY 2019
LA Italian
U1 0
U2 0
AB The Mediterranean genera of Reicheiina without pronotal prebasal edge
   are here examined: Alpiodytes Jeannel, 1957; Catalanodytes Sciaky, 1989;
   Spelaeodytes Miller, 1863; Ichnusodytes Magrini, Fancello & Onnis n.
   gen.; the last here established for Typhloreicheia nivis Magrini &
   Onnis, 2018, species recently described from Sardinia (Mount Arcueri
   (Nuoro)) (Ichnusodytes nivis (Magrini & Onnis, 2018) comb. nov.). The
   study of the male and female genitalia, and exoskeletal characters, does
   not reveal close phyletic relationships between these taxa. Important
   discrepancies are found in the descriptions of the monospecific genus
   Catalanodytes and its type species C. bellesi (Lagar Mascaro, 1971): the
   superior labrum has 5 marginal bristles, not 3, and the elytral marginal
   furrow ends at level of the base of the fifth stria, not second.
   Reflections on the issues regarding the evolutionary developments which
   have involved the representatives of the subtribe Reicheiina close the
   article.
C1 Magrini, Paolo; Univ Firenze, Museo Storia Nat, Via Romana 17, Florence,
   FI, I-50125, Italy, Italy.
EM duvalius@paolomagrini.it

   specimens, are well characterized, and easily distinguishable from each

DT Article
TI Two new species of the genus Coomansinema Ahmad and Jairajpuri, 1989
   (Nematoda: Dorylaimida) with a key to its species.
AU Ahmad, W. (ahmadwasim57@gmail.com) 
   Mushtaq, P.
   Shahnaz
   Kumar, S.
SO Helminthologia (Bratislava)
VL 56
IS 1
PS 42-52
PD Mar 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new species of the genus Coomansinema Ahmad and Jairajpuri, 1989 are
   described and illustrated. C. japonicum n. sp. is characterized by
   having medium size body (L= 1.40 - 1.45 mm); lip region truncate with
   completely amalgamated lips; amphideal fovea goblet - shaped; 16 - 20
   [mu]m long odontostyle; 23 - 25 [mu]m long odontophore; comparatively
   anterior position of the second pair of pharyngeal glands; amphidelphic
   female genital system; longitudinal vulva; males with 48 - 54 [mu]m long
   spicules; 7 - 8 spaced ventromedian supplements and tail long filiform
   in female and short conoid in male. C. longicaudatum n. sp. is
   characterized by having medium size body (L= 1.1 - 1.3 mm); lip region
   truncate, continuous with completely amalgamated lips; amphideal fovea
   cup - shaped; 16 - 17 [mu]m long odontostyle; 19 - 20 [mu]m long
   odontophore; comparatively anterior position of the second pair of
   pharyngeal glands; amphidelphic female genital system; transverse vulva,
   intestinal - prerectum junction with a tongue - like structure and 210 -
   269 [mu]m long filiform tail. A key to its seven valid species is
   provided.
C1 Ahmad, W.; Aligarh Muslim Univ, Dept Zool, Aligarh, Uttar Pradesh,
   202002, India, India.

PM 31662675
DT Article
TI Helminths of mustelids with overlapping ecological niches: Eurasian
   otter Lutra lutra (Linnaeus, 1758), American mink Neovison vison
   Schreber, 1777, and European polecat Mustela putorius Linnaeus, 1758.
AU Nugaraite, D. (dovile.nugaraite@vdu.lt) 
   Mazeika, V.
   Paulauskas, A.
SO Helminthologia (Bratislava)
VL 56
IS 1
PS 66-74
PD Mar 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 2
U2 4
AB This study presents the helminthological data on three mustelid species
   with overlapping ecological niches in Lithuania. In general, 14 helminth
   species or higher taxa were reported from all mustelids: Isthmiophora
   melis, Strigea strigis metacercariae, Pseudamphistomum truncatum, Alaria
   alata mesocercariae, Phyllodistomum folium, Opisthorchis felineus,
   Metametorchis skrjabini, Mesocestoides sp., Taenia martis, Aonchotheca
   putorii, Crenosoma schachmatovae, Eucoleus aerophilus, Molineus patens,
   and Nematoda g. sp. The largest number of helminths was detected in M.
   putorius (11) and N. vison (10) from wetlands; 7 helminths were detected
   in M. putorius from forests, and 8 in N. vison and 4 in L. lutra from
   water bodies. Habitat-related differences were found in the abundance
   and prevalence of E. aerophilus in M. putorius. M. putorius has higher
   indices of infection by I. melis, S. strigis metacercariae, and E.
   aerophilus compared to N. vison in wetlands. Differences in the
   abundance and prevalence of P. truncatum among N. vison and L. lutra in
   water bodies have been observed. Helminths detected in N. vison in the
   present study are native European parasites.

DT Article
TI Is Amphiorchis (Digenea: Spirorchiidae) an exclusive parasite of sea
   turtles?
AU Palumbo, E. (epalumbo@cepave.edu.ar) 
   Werneck, M.R.
   Diaz, J.I.
SO Helminthologia (Bratislava)
VL 56
IS 1
PS 75-80
PD Mar 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 1
U2 5
AB The side-necked turtle Hydromedusa tectifera commonly inhabits the
   tributary streams of the Rio de La Plata and occasionally is found in
   brackish waters within the estuary of the Rio de La Plata. Few studies
   have been conducted on its parasitic fauna, especially in Argentina. In
   the present work Amphiorchis sp. is registered for the first time in a
   freshwater turtle, expanding the knowledge about the specificity of the
   genus that until now was considered inhabiting only marine turtles.

PT J

PM 31662677
DT Article
TI Cercarial fauna of freshwater snails in selected agricultural areas in
   Laguna, Philippines.
AU Paller, V.G.V. (vvpaller@up.edu.ph) 
   Macaraig, J.R.M.
   Verona, R.T.
   Estano, L.A.
SO Helminthologia (Bratislava)
VL 56
IS 1
PS 81-86
PD Mar 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Freshwater snails serve as one of trematodes' intermediate hosts.
   Previous studies on trematode larval stages in the Philippines have
   largely focused on species with public health importance. This study
   sought to investigate the prevalence of cercarial morphotypes in several
   freshwater snail species found in different habitat types (rice field,
   irrigation canals, and residential area) in selected agricultural areas
   in Los Banos and Bay in Laguna. Cercarial emergence was induced through
   exposure to artificial light. A total of 2,720 freshwater snails were
   collected and were represented by seven species, namely, Melanoides
   tuberculata Muller 1774 (n = 1229), Radix quadrasi von Moellendorf (n =
   630), Tarebia granifera Lamarck, 1816 (n = 417), Pomacea canaliculata
   Lamarck 1819 (n = 257), Vivipara angularis philippinensis Nevill (n =
   18), Stenomelania sp. (n = 104), Thiara scabra Muller 1774 (n = 65). A
   2.57 % over-all prevalence was recorded; the infected snail species were
   M. tuberculata (2.21 %), R. quadrasi (0.21 %), T. granifera (0.11 %).
   Four cercarial morphotypes, namely, Parapleurolophocercous cercaria
   (1.80 %), Virgulate xiphidiocercaria (0.26 %), Megaluruous cercaria
   (0.29 %), and Echinostome cercaria (0.22 %) were recovered from the
   infected snail species. Prevalence of cercarial infection was
   significantly different (p < 0.05) among habitat types.
C1 Paller, V.G.V.; Univ Philippines Los Banos, Coll Arts & Sci, Laguna,
   Philippines, Philippines.
EM vvpaller@up.edu.ph
SC Parasitology; Zoology; Marine &Freshwater Biology; Environmental
   Sciences &Ecology
SN 0440-6605

   habitat; Land zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia

   philippinensis [Parasites / Trematoda (Platyhelminthes) / Prevalence;
   transmission; intermediate hosts] [Transmission of parasites /  / ]
   [Freshwater habitat / Agricultural areas / Platyhelminth parasites]

   Cerithioidea, Viviparoidea, Pulmonata, Basommatophora, Lymnaeoidea,
   Platyhelminthes
OR Melanoides tuberculata (Cerithioidea): [Host].

   Pomacea canaliculata (Viviparoidea): [Host].

   Radix quadrasi (Lymnaeoidea): [Host].

DT Article
TI Two New Species of Pristimantis (Amphibia: Anura: Strabomantidae) from
   Southwestern Colombia.
AU Ospina-Sarria, Jhon Jairo (sarriajhon@gmail.com) 
   Duellman, William E.
SO Herpetologica
VL 75
IS 1
PS 85-95
PD Mar 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB We describe two new species of Pristimantis from southwestern Colombia.
   The first new species inhabits the humid Pacific slopes of the
   Cordillera Occidental, Valle del Cauca; it is most similar to three
   allopatric Ecuadorian species-P. eugeniae (Lynch and Duellman 1997), P.
   nyctophylax (Lynch 1976), and P. subsigillatus (Boulenger 1902). It is
   distinguished, however, by having subarticular tubercles beneath the
   joint between distal phalanges, basal webbing on outer edge of toe IV,
   papilla at the tip of snout, and uniform cream-brown coloration on the
   anterior surfaces of thighs and in the groin. The second new species
   inhabits the high mountains of the Cordillera Central, Cauca, and it is
   most similar to P. boulengeri (Lynch 1981) and two Peruvian species-P.
   deyi Lehr et al. 2013 and P. schultei (Duellman 1990). However, it
   differs by having subarticular tubercles beneath the joint between
   distal phalanges, dorsal skin with low warts, papilla at the tip of
   snout, and by lacking tympanic membranes, dentigerous processes of the
   vomer, and vocal slits.

DT Article
TI First record of tropical sea urchin Echinometra sp. C from Honshu,
   Japan.
AU Nakano, Tomoyuki (nakano.tomoyuki.2a@kyoto-u.ac.jp) 
   Kawamura, Mariko
   Satoh, Takashi P.
SO Japanese Journal of Benthology
VL 73
IS 2
PS 109-117
PD Mar 2019
PY 2019
LA Japanese
U1 0
U2 0
AB Between 2013 and 2017, we collected 30 sea urchins that belonged to the
   genus Echinometra from Banshozaki Cape, Shirahama, Wakayama, Japan.
   These specimens included 6 greenish individuals that resemble
   Echinometra. sp. C (reported by Arakaki et al., 1998), a species
   distributed in only Okinawa and southwards. Molecular analysis based on
   partial sequences of the mitochondrial cytochrome oxidase subunit I gene
   (1,080 bp) suggested that the 30 sea urchins from Shirahama were
   Echinometra mathaei, Echinometra oblonga, Echinometra sp. A. and
   Echinometra sp. C. Five of the 6 greenish specimens were genetically
   identical to Echinometra sp. C from Okinawa. Triradiate spicules present
   in the gonads, a diagnostic character of Echinometra sp. C., further
   confirmed the taxonomy of the 5 individuals. The remaining green
   specimen was identified as Echinometra mathaei on the basis of both
   molecular analysis and spicule morphology. To the best of our knowledge,
   this is the first record of Echinometra sp. C on the main island of
   Japan (Honshu). Here, we have discussed the reasons for the emergence of
   tropical sea urchins around Banshozaki Cape, Shirahama.
C1 Nakano, Tomoyuki; Kyoto Univ, Seto Marine Biol Lab, 459 Shirahama,
   Nishimuro, Wakayama, 6492211, Japan, Japan.
EM nakano.tomoyuki.2a@kyoto-u.ac.jp
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Biochemistry &Molecular Biology; Genetics
   &Heredity; Evolutionary Biology; Meteorology &Atmospheric Sciences;
   Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 1345-112X
BD General morphology; Biochemistry; Genetics; Evolution; Abiotic factors;
   Physical factors; Marine zones; Pacific Ocean
DE Echinometra [General morphology /  / new record] [Nucleic acids / mtDNA
   COI gene sequences / ] [Molecular genetics /  / ] [Phylogeny /  / ]
   [Temperature /  / ] [North Pacific / Japan, Honshu / ]. 
TN Echinoderms; Invertebrates

OR Echinometra (Echinoidea): [New record].

DT Article
TI Emergence of sympatry in a radiation of subterranean amphipods.
AU Zaksek, Valerija (valerija.zaksek@bf.uni-lj.si) 
   Delic, Teo
   Fiser, Cene
   Jalzic, Branko
   Trontelj, Peter
SO Journal of Biogeography
VL 46
IS 3
PS 657-669
PD Mar 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 2
U2 9
AB Aim We tested the hypothesis that sympatry among closely related species
   is possible only in the absence of interspecific competition. Location
   Dinaric Karst, Western Balkan, Europe. Taxon A clade of subterranean
   amphipods, genus Niphargus (Crustacea: Amphipoda). Methods Phylogenetic
   reconstructions; species delimitation; modelling competition using
   phylogeny and species distributions; reconstruction of historical
   dispersal. Results The clade comprises six species, which classify into
   two ecomorphs. Species of the same ecomorph are parapatric or
   allopatric, whereas species belonging to different ecomorphs overlap
   their ranges. The phylo-spatial reconstructions suggest that the shift
   from allopatry to sympatry is associated with relaxation of competitive
   interactions. Reconstruction of species past dispersal implies that
   sympatry is of secondary origin. Main conclusions Interspecific
   competition presumably controls evolutionary and ecological dynamics in
   subterranean environments in a similar way as in more familiar surface
   environments.
C1 Zaksek, Valerija; Univ Ljubljana, Biotech Fac, Ljubljana, Slovenia,
   Slovenia.

   region; Eurasia

   / Molecular characterization / ] [Phylogeny /  / ] [Morphological
   variation /  / ] [Interspecific competition /  / ] [Sympatry /  / ]
   [Europe / Dinaric Karst / distribution].

   Niphargus subtypicus (Amphipoda): [Syn nov, Niphargus jalzici, p. 662].

PM 29938869
DT Article
TI A New Halophilic Heterolobosean Flagellate, Aurem hypersalina gen. n. et
   sp. n., Closely Related to the Pleurostomum-Tulamoeba Clade:
   Implications for Adaptive Radiation of Halophilic Eukaryotes.
AU Jhin, Soo Hwan
   Park, Jong Soo (jongsoopark@knu.ac.kr) 
SO Journal of Eukaryotic Microbiology
VL 66
IS 2
PS 221-231
PD Mar 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB Halophilic Protozoa are independently scattered across the molecular
   phylogeny of eukaryotes; most of which are assigned to Heterolobosea.
   Here, we isolated a biflagellate from a hypersaline water of 342[per
   mill] salinity. This isolate shared several morphological features with
   typical halophilic heterolobosean flagellates. In addition, molecular
   phylogenetic trees of the 18S rRNA gene sequences clearly indicated
   flagellate is a heterolobosean species closely related to the halophilic
   Tulamoebidae. However, the flagellate was not accommodated to any
   described genus. Cells were ovoid-shaped, and no amoebae were observed.
   The two unequal flagella beat heterodynamically. An ear-like bulge at
   the margin of a cytostomal groove was observed. Flagellates could grow
   at 100-200[per mill] salinity, suggesting an obligately halophilic
   species. Currently, it appears that the new halophilic Aurem hypersalina
   forms a strong clade with Tulamoebidae, and is sister to the
   Tulamoebidae, indicating that this new clade is composed almost entirely
   of obligate halophilic taxa. Thus, A. hypersalina and the Tulamoebidae
   clade currently represent a unique adaptive radiation of halophilic
   eukaryotes.
C1 Park, Jong Soo; Kyungpook Natl Univ, Sch Earth Syst Sci, 80 Daehakro,
   Daegu, 41566, South Korea, South Korea.
EM jongsoopark@knu.ac.kr
RI Park, Jong Soo/AAJ-3576-2020
OI Park, Jong Soo/0000-0001-6253-5199
SC Zoology
SN 1066-5234

   Eurasia; Asia
DE Aurem hypersalina [South Korea /  / New species]. 
TN Protozoans
ST Protozoa, Sarcomastigophora, Sarcodina, Rhizopoda
OR Aurem (Rhizopoda): [Gen nov, Of subphylum Tetramitia, Type species Aurem
   hypersalina, p. 225]. 
   Aurem hypersalina (Rhizopoda): [Sp nov, South Korea, P. 225]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15505031332

AN ZOOR15505031336

DT Article
TI Morphology and Phylogeny of Four New Vorticella Species (Ciliophora:
   Peritrichia) from Coastal Waters of Southern China.
AU Liang, Ziyao
   Shen, Zhuo
   Zhang, Yong
   Ji, Daode
   Li, Jiqiu
   Warren, Alan
   Lin, Xiaofeng (xlin@scnu.edu.cn) 
SO Journal of Eukaryotic Microbiology
VL 66
IS 2
PS 267-280
PD Mar 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 2
U2 14
AB Four new species of Vorticella, V. parachiangi sp. n., V. scapiformis
   sp. n., V. sphaeroidalis sp. n., and V. paralima sp. n., were isolated
   from coastal brackish waters of southern China. Their morphology,
   infraciliature, and silverline system were investigated based on
   observations of specimens both in vivo and following silver staining.
   Vorticella parachiangi sp. n. is distinguished by: a J-shaped
   macronucleus; a single dorsally located contractile vacuole; a two-rowed
   infundibular polykinetid 3, in which row 1 is shorter than row 2; 21-31
   silverlines between peristome and aboral trochal band, 6-11 between
   aboral trochal band and scopula. Vorticella scapiformis sp. n. is
   characterized by its conspicuously thin and irregularly edged
   peristomial lip; a J-shaped macronucleus; a single, ventrally located
   contractile vacuole; row 1 of the infundibular polykinetid 3 proximally
   shortened; 18-25 silverlines between peristome and aboral trochal band,
   8-12 between aboral trochal band and scopula. Vorticella sphaeroidalis
   sp. n. can be identified by its small, sub-spherical zooid; a C-shaped
   macronucleus; a ventrally located contractile vacuole; an aboral trochal
   band adjacent to the scopula; 16-18 silverlines between persitome and
   aboral trochal band, two between aboral trochal band and scopula.
   Vorticella paralima sp. n. can be identified by its ovoidal zooid; a
   J-shaped macronucleus; a dorsally positioned contractile vacuole; rows 1
   and 2 of the infundibular polykinetid 3 proximally shortened; 26-35
   silverlines from peristome to aboral trochal band, and 7-13 from aboral
   trochal band to scopula. The SSU rDNA genes of these four species were
   sequenced and their phylogeny was analyzed.
C1 Lin, Xiaofeng; South China Normal Univ, Lab Protozoa, Guangzhou,
   Guangdong, 510631, China, China.
EM xlin@scnu.edu.cn
SC Zoology
SN 1066-5234
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Marine zones; Pacific Ocean

   Vorticella sphaeroidalis [North Pacific / China, Guangdong / New
   species]. 
TN Protozoans

   (marine), P. 278].

DT Article
TI What Can Environmental Sequences Tell Us About the Distribution of
   Low-Rank Taxa? The Case of Euplotes (Ciliophora, Spirotrichea),
   Including a Description of Euplotes enigma sp. nov.
AU Boscaro, Vittorio (vittorio.boscaro@botany.ubc.ca) 
   Syberg-Olsen, Mitchell J.
   Irwin, Nicholas A.T.
   del Campo, Javier
   Keeling, Patrick J.
SO Journal of Eukaryotic Microbiology
VL 66
IS 2
PS 281-293
PD Mar 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 3
U2 7
AB Environmental sequences have become a major source of information.
   High-throughput sequencing (HTS) surveys have been used to infer
   biogeographic patterns and distribution of broad taxa of protists. This
   approach is, however, more questionable for addressing low-rank (less
   inclusive) taxa such as species and genera, because of the increased
   chance of errors in identification due to blurry taxonomic boundaries,
   low sequence divergence, or sequencing errors. The specious ciliate
   genus Euplotes partially escapes these limitations. It is a ubiquitous,
   monophyletic taxon, clearly differentiated from related genera, and with
   a relatively well-developed internal systematics. It has also been the
   focus of several ecological studies. We present an update on Euplotes
   biogeography, taking into consideration for the first time environmental
   sequences, both traditional (Sanger) and HTS. We inferred a
   comprehensive small subunit rRNA gene phylogeny of the genus including a
   newly described marine species, Euplotes enigma, characterized by a
   unique question mark-shaped macronucleus. We then added available
   environmental sequences to the tree, mapping associated metadata. The
   resulting scenario conflicts on many accounts with previously held
   views, suggesting, for example, that a large diversity of anaerobic
   Euplotes species exist, and that marine representatives of mainly
   freshwater lineages (and vice-versa) might be more common than
   previously thought.
C1 Boscaro, Vittorio; Univ British Columbia, Dept Bot, 3529-6270 Univ Blvd,
   Vancouver, BC, V6T 1Z4, Canada, Canada.
EM vittorio.boscaro@botany.ubc.ca
RI Boscaro, Vittorio/J-5857-2012; del Campo, Javier/B-5233-2008
OI Boscaro, Vittorio/0000-0003-4374-1231; del Campo,
   Javier/0000-0002-5292-1421
SC Genetics &Heredity; Zoology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 1066-5234
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Genetics; Evolution; Zoogeography;
   Marine zones; Pacific Ocean
DE Euplotes [Molecular genetics / Environmental sequences / systematics]
   [Phylogeny / Molecular phylogeny / ] [Zoogeography / Biogeography / ]. 
   Euplotes enigma [North Pacific / Canada, British Columbia / New
   species]. 
TN Protozoans
ST Protozoa, Ciliophora, Polyhymenophorea, Spirotrichia, Hypotrichida
OR Euplotes (Hypotrichida). 
   Euplotes enigma (Hypotrichida): [Sp nov, Canada, British Columbia
   (marine), P. 289]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15505031337
DA 2020-09-17

DT Article
TI A tentative new species Aphanomyces fennicus sp. nov. interferes with
   molecular diagnostic methods for crayfish plague.
AU Viljamaa-Dirks, Satu (satu.viljamaa-dirks@evira.fi) 
   Heinikainen, Sirpa
SO Journal of Fish Diseases
VL 42
IS 3
PS 413-422
PD Mar 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 1
U2 7
AB Several isolates of an unknown oomycete resembling the genus Aphanomyces
   were obtained into laboratory culture from samples of noble crayfish
   (Astacus astacus) in 2016-2017. The crayfish were kept in cages in
   connection with a study on an eventually persistent crayfish plague
   infection in a small Finnish lake, following an acute episode of the
   disease in 2010. Despite the close resemblance of the isolates to the
   causative agent of crayfish plague, Aphanomyces astaci, and the positive
   results obtained in OIE recommended A. astaci-specific ITS-based
   conventional PCR and qPCR molecular assays, the isolates can be
   distinguished from A. astaci by morphological features concerning hyphal
   structure and chlamydospore formation, as well as using the randomly
   amplified polymorphic DNA-polymerase chain reaction (RAPD-PCR) method,
   microsatellite-based genotyping, the pathogenicity test and phylogenetic
   analysis based on ITS sequencing. The name Aphanomyces fennicus sp.
   novum is proposed for this close relative of A. astaci. The detection of
   this tentative novel species giving false-positive results in existing
   diagnostic assays for the crayfish plague highlights the importance of
   careful interpretation of the results from molecular methods, especially
   concerning crayfish with low-level infections, excluding the possibility
   to verify the results from clinical or sequencing data.
C1 Viljamaa-Dirks, Satu; Finnish Food Safety Author Evira, Vet Bacteriol &
   Pathol Res Unit, Kuopio, Finland, Finland.
EM satu.viljamaa-dirks@evira.fi
RI Viljamaa-Dirks, Satu/D-6109-2016
OI Viljamaa-Dirks, Satu/0000-0002-1172-8852

SN 0140-7775

   diseases; Ecology; Population dynamics

   Decapoda, Reptantia, Astacura

DT Article
TI Monogenoidean parasites of Acestrorhynchus falcatus (Characiformes:
   Acestrorhynchidae) from Para, Brazil: species of Diaphorocleidus and
   Rhinoxenoides n. gen. (Monogenoidea: Dactylogyridae).
AU Santos, J.F., neto
   Costa, N.G.S.
   Soares, G.B.
   Domingues, M., V (mvdomingues@ufpa.br) 
SO Journal of Helminthology
VL 93
IS 2
PS 208-219
PD Mar 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Two new species of Diaphorocleidus and one new species of Rhinoxenoides
   n. gen. are described from the gills of Acestrorhynchus falcatus (Bloch)
   from rivers of north-eastern Para, Brazil. Diaphorocleidus
   jaymedeloyolai n. sp. is characterized by a male copulatory organ (MCO)
   possessing three counterclockwise coils; similar anchors with
   subtriangular superficial roots; a ventral bar with posteromedial
   projection; and hooks of pairs 1, 4 and 7 approximately three times
   longer than hook pair 5. Diaphorocleidus sclerocolpus n. sp. differs
   from its congeners by a dual-branched accessory piece articulated with
   the MCO and a sclerotized tubular vagina with a bottle-shaped vestibule.
   Rhinoxenoides n. gen. is proposed and is characterized by possessing:
   MCO sclerotized with clockwise coils; an accessory piece articulated to
   the base of MCO; a sinistroventral vaginal aperture; ventral anchor with
   conspicuous roots; dorsal anchor with superficial root five times longer
   than deep root; and absence of dorsal bar. The proposal of Rhinoxenoides
   n. gen. is also supported by its phylogenetic relationship with
   Protorhinoxenus prochilodi and species of Rhinoxenus, using 16
   morphological characters, which resulted in the following hypothesis of
   sister-group relationships: Rhinoxenoides n. gen. (Protorhinoxenus
   (Rhinoxenus curimatae (R. nyttus (R. bulbovaginatus (R. guianensis, R.
   piranhus, R. euryxenus (R. arietinus, R. anaclaudiae)))))).

DT Article
TI A new species of Parapharyngodon Chatterji, 1933 (Oxyuroidea:
   Pharyngodonidae), parasitic in Osteocephalus taurinus (Anura: Hylidae)
   from Brazil.
AU Santos, T.A.P.
   Argolo, E.G.G.
   Santos, A.N.
   Rodrigues, A.R.O.
   Gonzalez, C.E.
   Santos, J.N.
   Melo, F.T., V (ftiago@ufpa.br) 
SO Journal of Helminthology
VL 93
IS 2
PS 220-225
PD Mar 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Parapharyngodon politoedi n. sp. is described here, based on specimens
   found in the large intestines of Osteocephalus taurinus from the
   Caxiuana National Forest, State of Para, Brazil. The new species is
   assigned to Parapharyngodon based on the presence of non-embryonated
   eggs with sub-terminal opercula, when in the ovijector. Parapharyngodon
   politoedi belongs to a group of species with three pairs of cloacal
   papillae and differs from its congeners by morphometric aspects, such as
   the length of the spicule, and the combination of the following
   morphological characters: ovaries never encircling the oesophagus, tail
   shape in females, cloacal lips, sharply pointed spicule and presence of
   genital cone. This is the second species of nematode reported to
   parasitize O. taurinus and the eleventh species of Parapharyngodon from
   hylids in the Neotropical region.
C1 Melo, F.T., V; Univ Fed Para, Profa Dra Reinalda Marisa Lanfredi Inst
   Ciencias, Av Augusto Correa 01, Belem, Para, BR-66075110 BC, Brazil,
   Brazil.
EM ftiago@ufpa.br
RI NASCIMENTO DOS SANTOS, JEANNIE/F-7130-2012
OI NASCIMENTO DOS SANTOS, JEANNIE/0000-0002-6612-6410

   South America

PM 29743130
DT Article
TI Steinernema khuongi n. sp. (Panagrolaimomorpha, Steinernematidae), a new
   entomopathogenic nematode species from Florida, USA.
AU Stock, S.P. (spstock@email.arizona.edu) 
   Campos-Herrera, R.
   El-Borai, F.E.
   Duncan, L.W.
SO Journal of Helminthology
VL 93
IS 2
PS 226-241
PD Mar 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 1
U2 11
AB In this study, molecular (ribosomal sequence data), morphological and
   cross-hybridization properties were used to identify a new Steinernema
   sp. from Florida, USA. Molecular and morphological data provided
   evidence for placing the novel species into Clade V, or the
   'glaseri-group' of Steinernema spp. Within this clade, analysis of
   sequence data of the rDNA genes, 28S and internal transcribed spacer
   (ITS), depicted the novel species as a distinctive entity and closely
   related to S. glaseri and S. cubanum. Additionally, cross-hybridization
   assays showed that the new species is unable to interbreed with either
   of the latter two species, reinforcing its uniqueness from a biological
   species concept standpoint. Key morphological diagnostic characters for
   S. khuongi n. sp. include the mean morphometric features of the
   third-stage infective juveniles: total body length (average: 1066
   [mu]m), tail length (average: 65 [mu]m), location of the excretory pore
   (average: 80.5 [mu]m) and the values of c (average: 16.4), D% (average:
   60.5), E% (average: 126) and H% (average: 46.6). Additionally, males can
   be differentiated from S. glaseri and S. cubanum by the values of
   several ratios: D% (average: 68), E% (average: 323) and SW% (average:
   120). The natural distribution of this species in Florida encompasses
   both natural areas and citrus groves, primarily in shallow groundwater
   ecoregions designated as 'flatwoods'. The morphological, molecular,
   phylogenetic and ecological data associated with this nematode support
   its identity as a new species in the S. glaseri-group.
C1 Stock, S.P.; Univ Arizona, Dept Entomol, 1140 E South Campus Dr, Tucson,
   AZ, 85721, USA, USA.
EM spstock@email.arizona.edu

PM 29619918
DT Article
TI Meloidogyne daklakensis n. sp. (Nematoda: Meloidogynidae), a new
   root-knot nematode associated with Robusta coffee (Coffea canephora
   Pierre ex A. Froehner) in the Western Highlands, Vietnam.
AU Trinh, Q.P. (tqphap@gmail.com) 
   Le, T.M.L.
   Nguyen, T.D.
   Nguyen, H.T.
   Liebanas, G.
   Nguyen, T.A.D.
SO Journal of Helminthology
VL 93
IS 2
PS 242-254
PD Mar 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 2
U2 13
AB The root-knot nematode species Meloidogyne daklakensis n. sp. was
   discovered on the roots of Robusta coffee (Coffea canephora Pierre ex A.
   Froehner) in Dak Lak Province, Vietnam. This species is characterized by
   the females having rounded or oval perineal patterns, smooth, regular,
   continuous striae, and reduced lateral lines. The dorsal arch is low,
   rounded and encloses a quite distinct vulva and tail tip. The stylet is
   normally straight with well-developed and posteriorly sloped knobs. The
   males have a rounded cap that extends posteriorly into the lip region.
   The procorpus is outlined distinctly, and is three times longer than the
   metacorpus. The metacorpus is ovoid, with a strong valve apparatus. The
   species closely resembles M. marylandi, M. naasi, M. ovalis, M.
   panyuensis, M. lopezi, M. mali and M. baetica in the perineal pattern of
   the females, and the morphology of the males and the second-stage
   juveniles. Nonetheless, it can be differentiated from other species by a
   combination of morphometric, morphological and molecular
   characteristics. Phylogenetic analysis was conducted based on the
   internal transcribed spacer (ITS) and 28S rDNA as well as the region
   between the cytochrome c oxidase I (COI) and cytochrome c oxidase II
   (COII) mitochondrial genes. Herein, this nematode is described,
   illustrated, and designated as a new species, Meloidogyne daklakensis
   sp. n., based on morphometric, morphological and molecular analyses.
C1 Trinh, Q.P.; Grad Univ Sci & Technol, Vietnam Acad Sci & Technol, 18
   Hoang Quoc Viet, Hanoi, Vietnam, Vietnam.
EM tqphap@gmail.com
OI Nguyen, Tien/0000-0002-9476-935X; Trinh, Phap/0000-0001-9645-8291

   disorders; Hosts; Land zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia

   species] [Vietnam /  / New species from plant host].

DT Article
TI Re-examination of the Jurassic Mammaliaform Docodon victor by Computed
   Tomography and Occlusal Functional Analysis.
AU Schultz, Julia A.
   Bhullar, Bhart-Anjan S.
   Luo, Zhe-Xi (jaschultz@uchicago.edu) 
SO Journal of Mammalian Evolution
VL 26
IS 1
PS 9-38
PD Mar 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 1
U2 4
AB Docodon was the first described docodont, and has long featured
   prominently in the comparative and functional morphology of mammaliaform
   mandibles and teeth. We have now re-examined the dental and mandibular
   fossils of Docodon from Yale Quarry 9 at the Como Bluff site in the Late
   Jurassic Morrison Formation, using Computed Tomography (CT) scans and 3D
   image analyses. Our CT study revealed that some features used to
   distinguish the several Docodon species in historical studies many
   decades ago were based on incorrect manual restoration of mandibles, and
   on variable features of deciduous premolars, which are replaced in
   typical mammaliaform fashion. This supports a long-held notion that the
   multiple species of Docodon from the same quarry of the Morrison
   Formation are over-split and should be synonymized. We formally propose
   that the specimens examined in this study be synonymized under Docodon
   victor. Our new Occlusal Fingerprint Analysis (OFA) of Docodon molars
   supports the hypothesis that Docodon had a consistent dorso-posterior or
   palinal component in chewing in the disto-distolingual to distolingual
   direction. This helps to resolve the controversial historical
   alternative hypotheses postulated for tooth occlusion in the taxon. The
   Docodon occlusal pattern is likely a derived feature, evolved within
   Docodonta. A posterior component in theocclusal trajectory is a
   functional convergence of Docodon on unrelated traversodontid cynodonts.
C1 Luo, Zhe-Xi; Univ Chicago, Dept Organismal Biol & Anat, 1025 E 57Th St,
   Chicago, IL, 60637, USA, USA.
EM jaschultz@uchicago.edu
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology
SN 1064-7554
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Synonymy; Techniques; Musculature; Skeletal
   and supporting structures; Skeleton; Dentition; Skull; Land zones;
   Nearctic region; North America; USA; Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Docodon [Anatomical techniques / Computed tomography vs occlusal
   functional analysis / interpretation] [Skeletal musculature / Mandibular
   adductor muscle reconstruction / ] [Teeth /  / ] [Jaws / Mandible
   remains / ] [Wyoming / Como Bluff Site / ] [Jurassic / Late Jurassic /
   ]. 
TN Chordates; Mammals; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Mammalia, Docodonta
OR Docodon (Docodonta): [Fossil]. 
   Docodon victor - (Marsh 1880) (Docodonta): [Syn nov, Docodon crassus
   (Marsh 1887), p. 31; Syn nov, Docodon striatus Marsh 1881, p. 30].

DT Article
TI Functional and Systematic Implications of the Postcranial Anatomy of a
   Late Miocene Feline (Carnivora, Felidae) from Batallones-1 (Madrid,
   Spain).
AU Salesa, Manuel J. (msalesa@mncn.csic.es) 
   Siliceo, Gema
   Anton, Mauricio
   Peigne, Stephane
   Morales, Jorge
SO Journal of Mammalian Evolution
VL 26
IS 1
PS 101-131
PD Mar 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 1
U2 12
AB The Spanish late Miocene locality of Batallones-1 yielded a rich sample
   of large carnivorans, including saber-toothed felids, amphicyonids, and
   ailurids, but also of smaller species, with the small cats being
   especially interesting. Two species are known from Batallones-1, one of
   them the size of a wildcat, Felis silvestris, the other one the size of
   a caracal, Caracal caracal. The former is represented by skulls,
   mandibles, and postcranial bones, whereas the latter is known from a
   collection of long bones. Both species are less abundant than their
   larger relatives, the saber-toothed felids Promegantereon ogygia and
   Machairodus aphanistus, but the available sample allows us to assess
   body proportions and adaptations of the smallest species, and to propose
   a new genus for this feline, Leptofelis vallesiensis. Its limb bones are
   remarkably gracile compared to fossils of the earlier genera
   Pseudaelurus, Miopanthera, and Styriofelis, and comparable in cursorial
   adaptations to the wildcat, very different from extant arboreal cats.
   While middle Miocene felids were likely semi-arboreal forest dwellers,
   L. vallesiensis would be mostly terrestrial, climbing essentially for
   protection. This indicates an adaptation to a mosaic of habitats,
   including relatively open terrain, and may be related to the climatic
   changes detected in Eurasia during the late Miocene.
C1 Salesa, Manuel J.; CSIC, Museo Nacl Ciencias Nat, C Jose Gutierrez
   Abascal 2, Madrid, E-28006, Spain, Spain.
EM msalesa@mncn.csic.es

   Paleontology

   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods; Caenozoic;
   Tertiary; Neogene
DE Feliformia [Biomechanics /  / systematics; comparative study] [Skeleton
   / Postcranial anatomy / ] [Evolutionary adaptation /  / ] [Spain /

   Late Miocene / ].

DT Article
TI Phylogenetic and Morphological Analysis of Birch Mice (Genus Sicista,
   Family Sminthidae, Rodentia) in the Kazak Cradle with Description of a
   New Species.
AU Cserkesz, Tamas (cserkeszt@ceasar.elte.hu) 
   Fulop, Attila
   Almerekova, Shyryn
   Kondor, Tamas
   Laczko, Levente
   Sramko, Gabor
SO Journal of Mammalian Evolution
VL 26
IS 1
PS 147-163
PD Mar 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB Birch mice (genus Sicista) represent an early diverging lineage of
   dipodid rodents with a wide geographic distribution and a cryptic
   lifestyle that makes the genus difficult to study. As a result,
   reconstructing the evolutionary phylogeny of the group remains
   incomplete. Here, we report the molecular phylogeny of the genus based
   on mitochondrial and nuclear markers sampled from 12 of the 14 known
   living species. Moreover, we discuss morphological character (i.e., fur
   coloration and glans penis morphology) evolution in the genus. We have
   found a strong agreement between phylogenetic relationships among
   species and morphological peculiarities, both supporting a mountainous
   origin of Sicista, and a recent spread towards lowlands of some
   lineages. Glans penis structure turned out to be rather simple in the
   early lineages, but became more complex in phylogenetically later
   diverging taxa. The presence of dorsal stripes is associated with the
   colonization of lowland habitats. In addition, we describe here a
   species new to science from the Tien Shan Mountains, and provide
   evidence of uncovered cryptic diversity from the region. Additionally,
   we revise the identification of a specimen collected from China, thus
   documenting the presence of Sicista pseudonapaea, previously unreported
   from that country.
C1 Cserkesz, Tamas; Eotvos Lorand Univ, Dept Systemat Zool & Ecol, Pazmany

DT Article
TI Morphological and Molecular Analyses of Simulium rufibasis (Diptera:
   Simuliidae) in Thailand.
AU Takaoka, Hiroyuki (takaoka@oita-u.ac.jp) 
   Srisuka, Wichai
   Low, Van Lun
   Saeung, Atiporn
SO Journal of Medical Entomology
VL 56
IS 2
PS 408-415
PD Mar 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB A man-biting black fly species so far regarded as Simulium rufibasis
   Brunetti in Thailand was morphologically analyzed. It was found to be
   almost indistinguishable in the female from S. rufibasis sensu stricto
   but distinguishable in the male by the slender fore basitarsus and
   abdominal segments 2, 6, and 7 each with a pair of shiny dorsolateral
   patches, and in the pupa by the absence of spine-combs on abdominal
   segment 7 and terminal hooks on segment 9. It is described as a new
   species, Simulium tenebrosum. Taxonomic notes are given to separate it
   from all 11 known species of the S. rufibasis subgroup of the Simulium
   (Simulium) tuberosum species-group. An analysis of the COI gene
   sequences shows that this new species is distantly separated from the
   closely related species.
C1 Takaoka, Hiroyuki; Univ Malaya, Trop Infect Dis Res & Educ Ctr TIDREC,
   Kuala Lumpur, 50603, Malaysia, Malaysia.
EM takaoka@oita-u.ac.jp

AB Trichophoromyia iorlandobaratai sp. n. Vasconcelos dos Santos, Santos
   Neto, Sanchez Uzcategui & Galardo is described and illustrated on the
   basis of male specimens collected in the municipality of Itaituba, Para
   State, Brazilian Amazonia. This species can be differentiated from other
   morphologically similar species within Trichophoromyia by means of the
   male characters such as the ratio between the aedeagal ducts/sperm pump,
   shape and distribution of setae in the gonocoxite, and particularly the
   distinct shape of paramere.

TI A New Black Fly Species of the Simulium (Gomphostilbia) duolongum
   Subgroup (Diptera: Simuliidae) From Vietnam, and Molecular Comparisons
   With Related Species Using the COI Barcoding Gene.
AU Takaoka, Hiroyuki (takaoka@oita-u.ac.jp) 
   Low, Van Lun
   Tan, Tiong Kai
   Ya'cob, Zubaidah
   Sofian-Azirun, Mohd
   Chen, Chee Dhang
   Lau, Koon Weng
   Xuan Da Pham
SO Journal of Medical Entomology
VL 56
IS 2
PS 432-440
PD Mar 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Simulium (Gomphostilbia) yvonneae sp. nov. is described based on adults,
   pupae, and mature larvae from Vietnam. This new species belongs to the
   Simulium duolongum subgroup in the S. batoense species-group of the
   subgenus Gomphostilbia Enderlein. It is distinguished by having a
   relatively larger number of male upper-eye facets in 16 vertical columns
   and 16 horizontal rows and a pupal gill with eight filaments arranged as
   3+(1+2)+2 from dorsal to ventral, of which two filaments of the ventral
   pair are 1.8 times as long as the longest filament of the middle and
   dorsal triplets. Morphological comparisons are made to distinguish this
   new species from all 22 related species. The genetic distinctiveness of
   this new species in the S. duolongum subgroup is also presented based on
   the DNA barcoding COI gene.

DT Article
TI Ecology and Molecular Detection of Leishmania infantum Nicolle, 1908
   (Kinetoplastida: Trypanosomatida) in Wild-Caught Sand Flies
   (Psychodidae: Phlebotominae) Collected in Porto Alegre, Rio Grande do
   Sul: A New Focus of Visceral Leishmaniasis in Brazil.
AU Rego, Felipe Dutra
   Souza, Getulio Dornelles
   Pedroso Dornelles, Luiz Fernando
   Andrade Filho, Jose Dilermando (jandrade@cpqrr.fiocruz.br) 
SO Journal of Medical Entomology
VL 56
IS 2
PS 519-525
PD Mar 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 1
U2 5
AB Phlebotomine sand flies are hematophagous insect vectors of the
   protozoan parasites of the genus Leishmania Ross, 1903 (Kinetoplastida:
   Trypanosomatida) that infect mammals, including humans, causing
   leishmaniasis. In Porto Alegre, Brazil, three autochthonous cases of
   human visceral leishmaniasis were reported in 2016 through 2017. We
   analyzed for the presence of Leishmania DNA in sand flies collected at
   the neighborhood of Agronomia, Porto Alegre, Brazil. Phlebotomine sand
   flies were collected at three sites from October 2014 to September 2015.
   Female sand flies were pooled in numbers from 1 to 20 depending upon
   species, locality, and date; all were screened for Leishmania infection
   by the amplification of the ITS1 region. In total 518 phlebotomine sand
   flies were collected: Psathyromyia lanei (Barretto and Coutinho, 1941)
   (Diptera: Psychodidae) (30.5%), Brumptomyia sp. (Franca and Parrrot,
   1921) (Diptera: Psychodidae) (25.7%), Migonemyia migonei (Franca, 1920)
   (Diptera: Psychodidae) (21.4%), Pintomyia fischeri (Pinto, 1926)
   (Diptera: Psychodidae) (21.4%), and Nyssomyia neivai (Pinto, 1926)
   (Diptera: Psychodidae) (1.0%). Most sand flies were collected during the
   hot and rainy season from October 2014 to April 2015. Of the 113 pools
   analyzed, five pools of Pi. fischeri were PCR-positive with the
   amplicons possessing sequences similar (>95%) to that of Leishmania
   infantum Nicolle, 1908 (Kinetoplastida: Trypanosomatida). These results
   represent the first molecular detection of Le. infantum in Pi. fischeri.
   It is possible that Pi. fischeri is involved in the transmission cycle
   of Le. infantum in the studied area; however, further studies are needed
   to establish the true role of Pi. fischeri in the visceral leismaniasis
   cycle.
C1 Andrade Filho, Jose Dilermando; Fundacao Oswaldo Cruz FIOCRUZ, Inst Rene
   Rachou, Belo Horizonte, MG, Brazil, Brazil.
EM jandrade@cpqrr.fiocruz.br

   Andrade/B-7852-2013; Rego, Felipe D/S-6013-2017

DT Article
TI Rare and new Late Bathonian (Middle Jurassic) ammonites from Monte
   Kumeta, western Sicily.
AU Galacz, Andras (galacz@ludens.elte.hu) 
SO Neues Jahrbuch fuer Geologie und Palaeontologie Abhandlungen
VL 291
IS 3
PS 231-252
PD Mar 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB The Middle Jurassic sequence of the West Sicilian Monte Kumeta contains
   a faunal level with a very rich Late Bathonian ammonite assemblage. The
   typical Tethyan fauna with many representatives of phylloceratids and
   lytoceratids also yielded oppeliids, perisphinctids and other diagnostic
   forms (incl. the index Prohecticoceras blanazense Elmi, 1967) to date
   the assemblage as the lower, Blanazense Subzone of the Prohecticoceras
   retrocostatum Zone. The probably lower position of the assemblage within
   the Retrocostatum Zone precedes the general appearance of the Bathonian
   heteromorph genus Parapatoceras, thus two new genera (Kumetaceras n.
   gen, with type species K. enigmaticum n. sp. and Sikeliceras n. gen.
   with type species S. costatum n. sp.) are of special interest from the
   point of view of the origin and/or dimorphism of Bathonian-Callovian
   heteromorphs. Other new forms are also described: the strigoceratid
   Phlycticeras tenue n. sp., the oppeliid Paroecotraustes minor n. sp. and
   the perisphinctid Sicilisphinctes n. gen. (with type species S. incertus
   n. sp.) and Albanesiceras n. gen. (with type species A. damianoi n.
   sp.). Some other, rare ammonites are described in detail, further forms
   are figured and discussed shortly.
C1 Galacz, Andras; Eotvos L Univ, Dept Palaeontol, Pazmany Peter Setany
   1-C, Budapest, H-1117, Hungary, Hungary.
EM galacz@ludens.elte.hu
SC Zoology; Paleontology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 0077-7749

   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe; Italy; Geological time periods;
   Mesozoic

DT Article
TI Supergiants in Europe: on the cirolanid isopod Bathynomus A. MILNE
   EDWARDS, 1879 (Malacostraca, Peracarida) from the Plio-Pleistocene of
   Italy.
AU Hyzny, Matus (hyzny.matus@gmail.com) 
   Pasini, Giovanni
   Garassino, Alessandro
SO Neues Jahrbuch fuer Geologie und Palaeontologie Abhandlungen
VL 291
IS 3
PS 283-298
PD Mar 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB New well-preserved specimens of cirolanid isopods from the Pliocene of
   Orciano Pisano (Pisa, Tuscany) and from the Pleistocene of Poggio I Sodi
   (Castelnuovo Berardenga-Scalo, Siena, Tuscany and Podere
   dell'Infrascato, Volterra, Siena, Tuscany), assignable to Palaega
   sismondai RISTORI, 1891, allow a re-description of the species.
   Additionally, Palaega pisana PASINI & GARASSINO, 2012 originally
   described from the Pliocene of Tuscany is considered a junior subjective
   synonym of P. sismondai. All specimens represent posterior portions of
   the exoskeleton interpreted as moults. Based on the presence of
   pleotelsonic spines and the shape of uropods the species is transferred
   to Bathynomus; thus, a new combination Bathynomus sismondai is proposed
   herein. Additionally, Palaega steatopigia PASINI & GARASSINO, 2012 from
   the Pliocene of Emilia Romagna is considered a nomen dubium and is
   reassigned to Bathynomus sp. The size of preserved remains and the
   outline of uropods of B. sismondai suggest attribution to the supergiant
   species group. Today Bathynomus inhabits a large area of the Indo-West
   Pacific and the West Atlantic. This is the first formal report of
   Bathynomus from Europe, suggesting that representatives of the genus
   inhabited the Mediterranean not so long ago.
C1 Hyzny, Matus; Comenius Univ, Fac Nat Sci, Ilkovicova 6, Bratislava,
   SK-84215, Slovakia, Slovakia.
EM hyzny.matus@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 0077-7749

   Synonymy; Available name; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Geological time periods; Caenozoic;
   Quaternary; Tertiary; Neogene
DE Bathynomus [Europe /  / new record; systematics] [Pleistocene /  / ]
   [Pliocene /  / ].

PM 30637469
DT Article
TI Gymnurahemecus bulbosus gen. et sp. nov. (Digenea: Aporocotylidae)
   infecting smooth butterfly rays, Gymnura micrura (Myliobatiformes:
   Gymnuridae) in the northern Gulf of Mexico, with a taxonomic key and
   further evidence for monophyly of chondrichthyan blood flukes.
AU Warren, Micah B. (brett.warren@auburn.edu) 
   Ruiz, Carlos F.
   Whelan, Nathan V.
   Kritsky, Delane C.
   Bullard, Stephen A.
SO Parasitology Research
VL 118
IS 3
PS 751-762
PD Mar 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 1
U2 9
AB Gymnurahemecus bulbosus gen. et sp. nov. infects the heart of smooth
   butterfly rays, Gymnura micrura in the Gulf of Mexico. Gymnurahemecus
   differs from all other accepted aporocotylid genera by having one column
   of C-shaped lateral tegumental spines, a medial oesophageal bulb
   anterior to a diverticulate region of the oesophagus, inverse U-shaped
   intestinal caeca, a non-looped testis, an oviducal ampulla, a Laurer's
   canal, and a post-caecal common genital pore. The new species, the shark
   blood flukes (Selachohemecus spp. and Hyperandrotrema spp.), and the
   chimaera blood fluke Chimaerohemecus trondheimensis are unique by having
   C-shaped lateral tegumental spines. Selachohemecus spp. and the new
   species have a single column of lateral tegumental spines, whereas
   Hyperandrotrema spp. and C. trondheimensis have 2-7 columns of lateral
   tegumental spines. The new species differs from Selachohemecus spp. most
   notably by having an inverse U-shaped intestine. The other ray blood
   flukes (Orchispirium heterovitellatum, Myliobaticola richardheardi, and
   Ogawaia glaucostegi) differ from the new species by lacking lateral
   tegumental spines, a medial oesophageal bulb, and a Laurer's canal and
   by having a looped testis. Phylogenetic analysis using large subunit
   ribosomal DNA (28S) indicated that the new species is sister to the
   clade that includes the other sequenced adult blood fluke (O.
   glaucostegi), which infects a ray in Australia. These results agree with
   and extend previous morphology- and nucleotide-based phylogenetic
   assertions that the blood flukes of early-branching jawed craniates
   (Chondrichthyes) are monophyletic and phylogenetically separated from
   the blood flukes of later-branching ray-finned fishes (Actinopterygii:
   Euteleostei).
C1 Warren, Micah B.; Auburn Univ, Sch Fisheries Aquaculture & Aquat Sci,
   Auburn, AL, 36849, USA, USA.
EM brett.warren@auburn.edu
RI Kritsky, delane/AAD-9826-2020
OI Warren, Micah/0000-0002-5008-4826
SC Evolutionary Biology; Zoology; Parasitology
SN 0932-0113
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Evolution; Parasites
   diseases and disorders; Parasites; Helminth parasites; Hosts; Marine
   zones; Atlantic Ocean; North Atlantic

   to parasite species].

   parasite species] [Gulf of Mexico / USA, Alabama / New platyhelminth
   parasite species].

   host].

   (Pisces), p. 758; Parasite].

   species Gymnurahemecus bulbosus, p. 753].

   Parasite of Gymnura micrura (Pisces), p. 753; Parasite].

PM 30675672
DT Article
TI Morphological and molecular characterization of Myxobolus dibombensis
   sp. n. (Myxozoa: Myxobolidae), a parasite of the African carp
   Labeobarbus batesii (Teleostei: Cyprinidae) from Dibombe River,
   Cameroon.
AU Folefack, Guy Benoit Lekeufack
   Abdel-Baki, Abdel-Azeem S.
   Ateba, Nelly Ornelle Onana
   Fomena, Abraham
   Mansour, Lamjed (lmansour@ksu.edu.sa) 
SO Parasitology Research
VL 118
IS 3
PS 763-771
PD Mar 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Myxobolus dibombensis sp. n. (Cnidaria: Myxosporea: Bivalvulida) is
   described from the fins of the African carp, Labeobarbus batesii, based
   on morphological and molecular data. Prevalence of infection was 51.9%
   (67/129). Ovoid to spherical cyst-like plasmodia were found in the
   intrasegmental region and among the fin rays. No pathological changes
   were found in the fish host tissue surrounding the cyst-like plasmodia.
   Mature myxospores were ovoid in frontal view and lenticular in lateral
   view, with slightly truncated anterior and rounded posterior ends.
   Myxospores measured 16.8 (15.8-18.0) m long and 11.4 (10.0-13.0) m wide.
   There was a triangular intercapsular appendix measuring 3.8 (2.6-4.5) m
   long. Polar capsules were ovoid and slightly unequal in size, occupying
   approximately one-third of the myxospore length. The larger polar
   capsule measured 7 (6-8) m long and 3.6 (3-4) m wide, while the smaller
   one measured 5.8 (4.8-7.0) m long and 3 (2-4) m wide. The larger polar
   capsule contained nine to 11 filament coils, whereas the smaller one
   contained seven to nine coils. SSU rDNA gene sequence of M. dibombensis
   sp. n. did not match any sequences available in the GenBank. The
   similarity with available Myxobolus spp. sequences ranged from 65 to
   81%. The novel species clustered with M. algonquinensis, which infects
   the cyprinid Luxilus cornutus from Canada.
C1 Mansour, Lamjed; King Saud Univ, Dept Zool, Riyadh, 11451, Saudi Arabia,
   Saudi Arabia.
EM lmansour@ksu.edu.sa
RI Mansour, Lamjed/AAD-8613-2019; MANSOUR, Lamjed/U-3028-2017
OI MANSOUR, Lamjed/0000-0002-9415-9383

   /  / New myxozoan parasite species].

PM 30721355
DT Article
TI Morphological and molecular characterization of a new species Myxobolus
   gutturocola n. sp. (Myxozoa: Myxobolidae) from the throat of
   Hypophthalmichthys molitrix in China.
AU Liu, J.M.
   Zhang, J.Y.
   Zhao, Y.J. (zhaoyuanjuncqnu@126.com) 
SO Parasitology Research
VL 118
IS 3
PS 773-781
PD Mar 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Myxobolus gutturocola n. sp. was isolated from the throat of silver
   carp, Hypophthalmichthys molitrix, in Chongqing, China. Myxospore valves
   are unsymmetrical and smooth. Mature spores are ellipsoidal in frontal
   view, measuring 12.5[plus or minus]0.2m (n=25) in length, 8.4[plus or
   minus]0.2m (n=25) in width and 7.1[plus or minus]0.2m (n=25) in
   thickness. Each spore has two pyriform and unequal sizes polar capsules,
   the large one with 5.7[plus or minus]0.2m in length x3.6[plus or
   minus]0.2m in width and the small one with 4.6[plus or minus]0.2m in
   length x2.6[plus or minus]0.1m in width. Polar filaments are coiled
   seven or eight turns in the large polar capsule and four or five turns
   in the small polar capsule. The coils are arranged almost
   perpendicularly to the longitudinal axis of the polar capsule.
   Morphological analysis revealed that M. gutturocola n. sp. is distinct
   from related species of Myxobolus Butschli, 1882. Molecular analysis has
   demonstrated that its SSU rDNA sequences do not match with any available
   sequences in GenBank. Phylogenetic analysis of the SSU rDNA sequences
   indicated this species clustered in a clade composed exclusively of
   parasites infecting the fishes of the Leucisini lineage and most closely
   related to Myxobolus pavlovskii isolated from the gill filaments of
   silver carp in Hungary.
C1 Zhao, Y.J.; Chongqing Normal Univ, Chongqing Key Lab Anim Biol,
   Chongqing, 401331, China, China.
EM zhaoyuanjuncqnu@126.com

SN 0932-0113

   disorders; Parasites; Hosts; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia;
   Asia; China

   / New parasite species] [Chongqing /  / New myxozoan parasite species]. 
   Myxobolus gutturocola [Piscean hosts / Hypophthalmichthys molitrix / New
   parasite species] [Chongqing /  / New species from piscean host].

DT Article
TI A new abyssal amphipod species (Crustacea) from sunken wood described
   using integrative taxonomy.
AU Jazdzewska, Anna Maria (anna.jazdzewska@biol.uni.lodz.pl) 
   Ziemkiewicz, Aleksandra
SO Progress in Oceanography
VL 172
PS 1-13
PD Mar 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB During the expedition to the abyssal plain of Kuril-Kamchatka (KuramBio
   I) wood fragments were collected at seven stations. One of the
   wood-falls harboured a group of amphipods belonging to the genus
   Bathyceradocus known to be associated with this type of habitat.
   Morphological study of the collection revealed that the crustaceans
   belong to species new to science. The species presently described
   differs from known congeners in the armature of the mandibular palp, the
   shape of gnathopod 2, the shape of coxa 4 as well as the shape of the
   basis of pereopods 5-7. The studied collection consists of females (one
   ovigerous), two males and juveniles, so size specific variation is also
   provided. It is the first record of Bathyceradocus in the Northwest
   Pacific and the fourth wood-associated amphipod species found in abyssal
   depths. Because the material was available for genetic study, cytochrome
   c oxidase I subunit (COI) sequences were analysed and six haplotypes
   were distinguished. There was relatively high intraspecific variation
   taking into account that all individuals came from a single station.
C1 Jazdzewska, Anna Maria; Univ Lodz, Fac Biol & Environm Protect, 12-16
   Banacha St, Lodz, PL-90237, Poland, Poland.
EM anna.jazdzewska@biol.uni.lodz.pl
RI Jazdzewska, Anna/AAK-4697-2020
OI Jazdzewska, Anna/0000-0003-2529-0641
SC Zoology
SN 0079-6611
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Marine zones; Pacific
   Ocean
DE Bathyceradocus [North Pacific / Russia / New record; systematics]. 
   Bathyceradocus hawkingi [North Pacific / Russia / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates

   Peracarida, Amphipoda
OR Bathyceradocus - Pirlot 1934 (Amphipoda): [Diagnostic characters of
   subordinate taxa, P. 10; New record]. 
   Bathyceradocus hawkingi (Amphipoda): [Sp nov, Russia (marine), P. 3]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15505030306
DA 2020-09-17

AN ZOOR15505029975
DT Article
TI Spionidae (Annelida) from Rishiri Island, Northern Japan.
AU Abe, Hirokazu
   Tomioka, Shinri
   Kobayashi, Genki
   Itoh, Hajime
SO Rishiri Studies
VL 38
PS 15-27
PD Mar 2019
PY 2019
LA Japanese
U1 0
U2 0
AB A faunal survey on spionid polychaetes was carried out in Rishiri
   Island, Hokkaido, northern Japan during July 28 to August 2, 2017.
   Annelid worms of the family Spionidae were collected from intertidal and
   shallow subtidal (< 5 m in depth) zones in six sampling sites
   (Motodomari, Oshidomari, Shinminato, Oniwaki, Numaura, and Senhoshi).
   Totally, 11 spionid species belonging to eight genera were collected:
   Polydora onagawaensis, Boccardiella hamata, Boccardia Proboscidea,
   Pseudopolydora paucibranchiata, Spio arndti, Sp. borealis, Sp.
   kurilensis, Sp. unidentata, Rhynchospio glutaea complex sp., Scolelepis
   kudenovi, and Aonides oxycephala. All 11 species were recorded for the
   first time from Rishiri Island. Spio arndti, Sp. kurilensis, and Sp.
   unidentata were newly recorded from Japan. New Japanese names for Sp.
   kurilensis and Sp. unidentata were proposed in the present paper.
   Voucher specimens were deposited in the Rishiri Town Museum (RTM),
   Rishiri Island, Hokkaido, Japan, under the museum registration numbers
   RTMANL002-RTMANL034.
C1 Abe, Hirokazu; Iwate Med Univ, Dept Biol, Nishitokuta 2-1-1, Yahaba,
   Iwate, 0283694, Japan, Japan.
